story_headline: Biden‚Äôs officials doing damage control ahead of recession numbers
story_copy: The Biden administration is downplaying concerns of a recession ahead of this week‚Äôs GDP numbers that are expected to show an economic downturn. In a statement Monday, the White House questioned how economists determine a recession while alleging the US economy is ‚Äútransitioning‚Äù from ‚Äò‚Äùfast growth‚Äù to steady and slow growth.Biden economic advisor Brian Deese: ‚ÄúWe are seeing a slowing [economy], that is not only expected but necessary, as we operate through this transition.‚Äù pic.twitter.com/9wiJH8NP4Y‚Äî RNC Research (@RNCResearch) July 25, 2022The US GDP shrank 1.6 percent in the first quarter and the Atlanta Fed expects it to fall another 2.1 percent in the second quarter. However, President Biden‚Äôs officials are claiming two quarters of negative growth does not indicate a recession although it does. The Bureau of Economic Analysis will release its advance estimate of second quarter GDP on Thursday, July 28.Biden economic advisor Jared Bernstein downplays the slowing economy and recession concerns as ‚Äúsemantics‚Äù pic.twitter.com/4AcVyILrae‚Äî RNC Research (@RNCResearch) July 25, 2022Meanwhile, former Treasury Secretary and Obama administration economic adviser Larry Summers blames a possible upcoming recession on high government spending.¬† In an interview Sunday, Summers said the Biden administration borrowed too much money over the past two years. As a result, the US national debt surged above $30 trillion.‚ÄúI think there is a very high likelihood of recession when we‚Äôve been in this kind of situation before,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúRecession has essentially always followed when inflation has been high and unemployment has been low.‚ÄùSummers said the US economy may face high inflation and no growth for a while.¬† The US government is set to release second quarter GDP figures later this week and if it is negative that would mean the country is officially in a recession.
image_caption: Brian Deese, Assistant to the President and Director of the National Economic Council, speaks during a meeting where President Joe Biden appeared virtually with his economic team in the South Court Auditorium on the White House complex in Washington, Friday, July 22, 2022. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)

story_headline: Ore. Antifa thugs attack biker event, get beaten
story_copy: Ore. Antifa thugs attack biker event, get beatenNEW YORK, NY ‚Äì APRIL 11: People hold Antifa flags at Trump Tower to counter protest the ‚ÄúWhite Lives Matter‚Äù march and rally on April 11, 2021 in New York City. (Photo by David Dee Delgado/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:20 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Oregon bikers took out the trash after a local branch of Antifa declared war on the motorcycle club. According to reporting by the Post Millennial and several Twitter accounts, Antifa activists besieged the Honky Tonk Bar in Salem, Oregon last week which began their feud with bikers.Breaking: #Antifa members including Clifford Eiffler-Rodriguez (in blue top & hat) gathered for a direct action to shut down the Honky Tonk bar in Salem, Ore. but were met by a group of bikers. One of the Antifa begins macing people before retreating. pic.twitter.com/08i6D89Oza‚Äî Andy Ng√¥ üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà (@MrAndyNgo) July 16, 2022At the time, bikers were holding the Hero Appreciation Day at the bar which Antifa deemed as a ‚Äúracist‚Äù and ‚Äúwhite supremacist‚Äù gathering. When Antifa showed up in black bloc, their numbers were very few. Still, they used a megaphone to draw attention to the gathering across the street from the bar. Eventually, several patrons made their way over to confront the demonstrators. Arguing turned into shoving, mace was deployed by an Antifa member and then the group retreated away from the establishment entirely. Antifa activists are now making threats against bikers online.It‚Äôs not like Antifa is unfamiliar with physical confrontation. Per Andy Ngo, one of the organizers of the demonstration at the Honky Tonk Bar was arrested in 2021 after allegedly hitting a female police officer. Ngo claimed another in attendance plead guilty the week before for doing over $164,000 in damages to a courthouse.Salem #Antifa member Clifford Phillip Eiffler-Rodriguez (in blue), a convicted fraudster, was one of the organizers of today's failed direct action against the Honky Tonk Bar. He was previously arrested at a violent protest last year where he allegedly hit a female officer. pic.twitter.com/WB6hxgMsbT‚Äî Andy Ng√¥ üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà (@MrAndyNgo) July 17, 2022The attempted #Antifa attack on the Honky Tonk Bar in Salem, Ore. ended in humiliation for Antifa members today. They lacked the numbers to launch assaults & were met by a group of angry women & bikers. Antifa also appeared to have now ignited a feud with a motorcycle club. pic.twitter.com/lSKfgKCyDI‚Äî Andy Ng√¥ üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà (@MrAndyNgo) July 17, 2022White Rose of the Willamette Valley used its Twitter account to complain after Salem Police didn‚Äôt protect their fellow Antifa members during the confrontation. It said Free Souls and ‚Äúother uniformed security‚Äù both ‚Äúattacked and injured community members peacefully protesting‚Äù without supplying details or other evidence. Unlawful Whatever on Twitter claimed ‚Äúone of ours‚Äù was hospitalized from the fight, retweeting a different person claiming ‚ÄúSalem police literally backed away‚Äù when the Free Souls came out to confront them.Free Souls MC and other uniformed security attacked and injured community members peacefully protesting the far-right event at Honky Tonk tonight engaging in physical assault and bear spray attacks. Again @cityofsalem @SalemPoliceDept is this what you accept here?‚Äî White Rose Of the Willamette Valley (@WhiteRoseOfSal1) July 16, 2022Oregon biker groups including the Free Souls Motorcycle Club warned Antifa to stay away from their venues and events going forward.
image_caption: NEW YORK, NY ‚Äì APRIL 11: People hold Antifa flags at Trump Tower to counter protest the ‚ÄúWhite Lives Matter‚Äù march and rally on April 11, 2021 in New York City. (Photo by David Dee Delgado/Getty Images)

story_headline: Same-sex marriage needs 10 GOP senators for codification
story_copy: Same-sex marriage needs 10 GOP senators for codificationFILE ‚Äì Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, speaks during hearing on the fiscal year 2023 budget for the FBI in Washington, May 25, 2022. A bipartisan group of senators, including Collins, released proposed changes July 20, to the Electoral Count Act, the post-Civil War-era law for certifying presidential elections that came under intense scrutiny after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol and Donald Trump‚Äôs effort to overturn the 2020 election. (Ting Shen/Pool Photo via AP, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 11:24 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Forty-seven House Republicans joined every Democrat in backing codification of same-sex marriage, in turn, sending the bill to the Senate. Now in the upper chamber, the bill, which would repeal the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act, codify interracial marriage and give legislative backing to the Supreme Court‚Äôs Obergefell decision, could face an uphill battle to the 60 votes needed for passage.All 50 Democrats have announced their support for gay marriage with the onus falling squarely on 10 Republican senators to join them and send the bill to President Joe Biden‚Äôs desk. Sen. Susan Collins of Maine has led Republican efforts to codify gay marriage while working closely with the Senates first openly lesbian member, Democrat Tammy Baldwin of Wisconsin, to try and secure the 10 GOP votes. Alaska‚Äôs Lisa Murkowski, Ohio‚Äôs Rob Portman and North Carolina‚Äôs Thom Tillis have also announced their support.If you are a Senator who supports marriage equality then you will support our bipartisan Respect for Marriage Act to protect this freedom and right for same-sex and interracial marriages. Let's stand together and protect the progress we have made.‚Äî Sen. Tammy Baldwin (@SenatorBaldwin) July 20, 2022However, even staunch conservatives are getting on board with the bill as Wisconsin‚Äôs Ron Johnson has announced his intention to vote ‚Äòyes.‚Äô He said that while he thinks the bill is unnecessary because overturning gay marriage would disrupt people‚Äôs lives in a way overturning abortion did not, he wouldn‚Äôt oppose its passage.‚ÄúUnlike Roe v. Wade, this pretty well is settled law from the standpoint that people have relied on that and if you overturn it, that‚Äôs a big part of Stare Decisis, it would disrupt a lot of people‚Äôs lives,‚Äù Johnson stated. ‚ÄúRoe v. Wade was about affecting people in the future‚Ä¶as I look at that piece of legislation from the House right now, I don‚Äôt see any reason why I should oppose it.‚ÄùDespite this, opposition still runs steep among some parts of the Senate Republican caucus. South Carolina‚Äôs Lindsey Graham has said that he would continue to support the Defense of Marriage Act passed in 1996 with majority support among both parties in both chambers and signed by Democrat President Bill Clinton.The Republican Whip in the Senate, Texas‚Äô John Cornyn, who‚Äôs fresh off writing the latest anti-Second Amendment legislation with Democrats, has said he feels the issue is an unnecessary distraction because it‚Äôs already settled law.‚ÄúI I think it‚Äôs a contrived issue because the Supreme Court‚Äôs decided the issue, so I don‚Äôt see any reason for the Congress to act,‚Äù he stated.Ted Cruz, Texas‚Äô other Republican senator, along with a few others are also expected to vote ‚Äòno.‚Äô The rest of the caucus remains cagey about giving a direct answer on where they sit. Iowa‚Äôs Joni Ernst has said she needs time to review the legislation and Utah‚Äôs Mitt Romney believes the bill is unnecessary, but is looking into it.Louisiana‚Äôs Bill Cassidy didn‚Äôt say if he would support the bill, but did tell reporters he was amazed they fall for distractions by the Democrats listed off a litany of pressing issues facing the country from a wide open border to record inflation. He said the whole thing was to shift the media‚Äôs attention from those issues.With most Republicans not giving a firm answer one way or the other, it could be a bill with an unknown status until it comes to the floor for a full vote by the body. If it passes, Biden has said he will sign it the moment it gets to his desk. However, even if the bill fails, same sex marriage will still be the law of the land for the foreseeable future with Republican legislators and Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh asserting the Obergefell decision isn‚Äôt going anywhere anytime soon.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, speaks during hearing on the fiscal year 2023 budget for the FBI in Washington, May 25, 2022. A bipartisan group of senators, including Collins, released proposed changes July 20, to the Electoral Count Act, the post-Civil War-era law for certifying presidential elections that came under intense scrutiny after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol and Donald Trump‚Äôs effort to overturn the 2020 election. (Ting Shen/Pool Photo via AP, File)

story_headline: Dem. Rep. Luria: Liz Cheney should be face of GOP
story_copy: Dem. Rep. Luria: Liz Cheney should be face of GOPFILE ‚Äì Rep. Elaine Luria, D-Va., speaks as the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol holds a hearing at the Capitol in Washington, Thursday, July 21, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:49 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Democrat Rep. Elaine Luria said she wants Liz Cheney to be the face of the Republican Party. Speaking to Meet the Press on Sunday, the Virginian said she has become good friends with the Wyoming Rep. since working together on Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs (D-Calif.) January 6 committee. According to Luria, even if Cheney loses her primary her voice is vital for the future of the GOP.‚ÄúI admire Liz Cheney,‚Äù Luria said. ‚ÄúI have been friendly with her ever since I came to Congress, even before we served on this committee together. I think that if she doesn‚Äôt come through this primary, come back to Congress, there are so many things that she could do in the future for our country.‚ÄùWhile Democrats promote Cheney, Republicans have repudiated the Rep. to the highest degree. The Wyoming Republican Party has formally censured her and no longer recognizes her as a member of the party.‚ÄúHer voice is absolutely needed,‚Äù Luria added. ‚ÄúAnd I think she‚Äôs one of unfortunately, a very small number of people who need to be the face of the Republican Party in the future. I would love to get back to where we had two political parties that debate on issues and facts and not lies. I really hope that Liz Cheney will continue, but I don‚Äôt want to speculate. She‚Äôs said herself she doesn‚Äôt know what her future plans will be.‚ÄùTwo profiles in courage: Liz Cheney & Elaine Luria. Both willing to put country before party even though it may cost them reelection in November. We need more people with this level of commitment to democracy in Congress, not fewer.‚Äî Joyce Alene (@JoyceWhiteVance) July 22, 2022In an extremely rare move, the RNC and Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) have thrown their support behind Rep. Hageman (R-Wyo.) which put the former vice president‚Äôs daughter on the outs.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Rep. Elaine Luria, D-Va., speaks as the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol holds a hearing at the Capitol in Washington, Thursday, July 21, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)

story_headline: WH: WHO announcement a ‚Äòcall to action‚Äô for global community
story_copy: WH: WHO announcement a ‚Äòcall to action‚Äô for global communityNEW YORK, NY ‚Äì SEPTEMBER 29: Ethiopia Minister of Foreign Affairs Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus speaks on stage during the Unleashing Women‚Äôs Economic Opportunites session during the 2015 Clinton Global Initiative at the Sheraton New York Times Square Hotel on September 29, 2015 in New York City. (Photo by JP Yim/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 12:01 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022The White House agreed with the World Health Organization‚Äôs decision to declare the spread of Monkeypox a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. They expressed that it is a ‚Äúcall to action.‚Äù In a statement Saturday, the Director of the White House Pandemic Preparedness Office Raj Panjabi claimed that an international response was essential to stop the spread. The World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus made the decision to declare the PHEIC after two separate deliberations with an emergency committee.‚ÄúA coordinated, international response is essential to stop the spread of Monkeypox,‚Äù Panjabi said. ‚ÄúIt will protect communities at greatest risk of contracting the disease and combat the current outbreak.‚ÄùWith the tools we have right now, we can stop #monkeypox transmission and bring this outbreak under control. It‚Äôs essential that all countries work closely with affected communities to adopt measures that protect their health, human rights and dignity.pic.twitter.com/DqyvRtB8w2‚Äî Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus (@DrTedros) July 23, 2022According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as of Friday there are close to 2,900 cases of Monkeypox that have been reported in the US. The states with the highest case counts are in New York, California, Florida, Illinois and Georgia. More than 16,000 cases have been reported in 75 countries and territories.‚ÄúSo in short, we have an outbreak that has spread around the world rapidly through new modes of transmission about which we understand too little and which meets the criteria in the international health regulations,‚Äù he voiced.The White House also maintained that the current administration has implemented a complex strategy to combat Monkeypox outbreaks in the US. They are dramatically scaling the procurement, distribution and production of vaccines.Today, OSTP released the Monkeypox Research Priorities to accelerate operational research and evidence to strengthen the ongoing global monkeypox outbreak response. https://t.co/VuwhaqDxHD‚Äî White House Office of Science & Technology Policy (@WHOSTP) July 21, 2022The Department of Health and Human Services¬†announced earlier this month¬†another 144,000 doses of the Jynneos vaccine would be distributed in addition to the more than 41,000 doses given out already to combat the virus, which is generally spread through contact directly with body fluids, rashes and scabs and prolonged face-to-face contact.
image_caption: NEW YORK, NY ‚Äì SEPTEMBER 29: Ethiopia Minister of Foreign Affairs Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus speaks on stage during the Unleashing Women‚Äôs Economic Opportunites session during the 2015 Clinton Global Initiative at the Sheraton New York Times Square Hotel on September 29, 2015 in New York City. (Photo by JP Yim/Getty Images)

story_headline: Biden‚Äôs Commerce Secy: China tariffs may be lifted
story_copy: Biden‚Äôs Commerce Secy: China tariffs may be liftedCommerce Secretary Gina Raimondo at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Washington, D.C. (Photo by Paul Morigi/Getty Images for Fortune/Time Inc)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:10 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo confirmed that the Biden administration is considering lifting tariffs on China. In an interview Sunday, Raimondo said officials are looking at potential labor implications of lifting Trump-era tariffs on China. She added that tariffs could be lifted if it helps bring down inflation and alleviate supply chain problems.The Secretary¬†also praised Biden‚Äôs so-called green agenda despite concerns it may further cripple US manufacturing. Despite¬†an analysis by the Peterson Institute for International Economics¬†that lifting tariffs on some Chinese-made products would save households hundreds of dollars, Biden is concerned about the support of unions in making this decision.‚ÄúThere are potential labor implications,‚Äù Raimondo stated. ‚ÄúOne thing about this president is he will never do anything that he thinks will hurt workers in America or union workers in America.‚Äù¬†Labor unions are actively campaigning against dropping tariffs on China with multiple groups filing an official comment to the Office of the US Trade Representative earlier this month to advocate for the tariffs to stay in place. Trump imposed numerous tariffs on China during his time in office. The former president believed that trading practices with the country were unfair to the US. The Biden administration has kept many of the tariffs in place despite indicating some of the policies need to be changed.‚ÄúThe labor market is now extremely strong,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis is not an economy that‚Äôs in recession, but we‚Äôre in a period of transition in which growth is slowing. And that‚Äôs necessary and appropriate, and we need to be growing at a steady and sustainable pace.‚ÄùThe Commerce Secretary herself advocated for dropping some of the tariffs, but there is no clear timeline on when the president will make a decision on the issue. Biden‚Äôs thinking could also be impacted by the midterm elections where union support is a big help to Democrats in a year where Republicans are expected to pick up multiple seats.The President is still weighing whether or not to lift tariffs off of China. The action potentially could have an impact on US inflation. @POTUS has said he plans to talk to China's Xi within days. https://t.co/mQq2r8jBU4‚Äî Margaret Brennan (@margbrennan) July 24, 2022Raimondo voiced that the Biden administration may restrict the exports of US technology to prevent it from falling into the wrong hands.
image_caption: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Washington, D.C. (Photo by Paul Morigi/Getty Images for Fortune/Time Inc)

story_headline: NYC Mayor Adams announces student debt relief program for mental health professionals
story_copy: NYC Mayor Adams announces student debt relief program for mental health professionalsFILE ‚Äì Mayor Eric Adams speaks during a graduation ceremony at Madison Square Garden, on July 1, 2022, in New York. (AP Photo/John Minchillo, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 12:02 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022New York City Mayor Eric Adams announced the launch of a student debt relief program for mental health professionals. During a press conference Sunday, Adams said the Behavioral Health Loan Repayment Program was funded by an anonymous $1 million donation and is designed to help attract and retain healthcare providers.Learn more about the @NYCHealthSystem Behavioral Health Loan Repayment Program (BH4NYC) at https://t.co/ijsBkIiUon. Applications are now open! https://t.co/3JF0OOQxes‚Äî Mayor's Office of Community Mental Health (@MentalHealthNYC) July 25, 2022Under the program, New York City health and hospitals will offer psychiatrists, nurse practitioners, psychologists and licensed clinical social workers who work three years in the hospital system between $30,000 and $50,000 of debt relief.¬† Applications for the program begin Monday and run through November 25 and will reopen in January for a second round.Mayor Eric Adams Makes Health and Education Related Announcement:
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Mayor Eric Adams speaks during a graduation ceremony at Madison Square Garden, on July 1, 2022, in New York. (AP Photo/John Minchillo, File)

story_headline: Sen. Cotton: No due process in J6 show trial
story_copy: Sen. Cotton: No due process in J6 show trialWASHINGTON, DC ‚Äì OCTOBER 27: Sen. Tom Cotton (R-AR) questions U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland as he testifies at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing about oversight of the Department of Justice on October 27, 2021 in Washington, DC. (Photo by Tasos Katopodis-Pool/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:50 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Senator Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) lamented the January 6 show trial is not fair or competitive. In an interview on Monday, Cotton said the Democrat-run panel has ‚Äúno adversarial process‚Äù and it‚Äôs essentially denying due process to its targets.He stressed that there‚Äôs no one on the January 6 committee whose view of the Capitol protest would be different than Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs (D-Calif.). Cotton voiced that the two Republicans on that committee are no different than Democrats in their assessments of those events.‚ÄúThere is no one on that committee who takes a view different from Nancy Pelosi or even a view that‚Äôs like we should examine the full context of all of these statements, of all of these recordings, of all of this video,‚Äù Cotton said. ‚ÄúWe have no idea of the videos and the audio recordings and the testimony is being presented in its full context.‚ÄùHugh Hewitt, the host of the Hugh Hewitt Show asked him ‚ÄúWhat is the principal defect of this committee?‚Äù‚ÄúThat it has no adversarial process whatsoever,‚Äù he replied. ‚ÄúLiz Cheney (Wyo.) and Adam Kinzinger (Ill.), the two Republicans, clearly share the views of the Democrats on the subject of the committee‚Äôs inquiry. If you had someone like Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) or Jim Banks (R-Ind.) on there, not only would they be privy to all the information, but they would be probing that information and probing witnesses to try to get at truth. Which is again what the Anglo-American legal system has done for centuries.‚ÄùMAGA Republicans claim that the J6 committee hearings amount to a ‚Äúshow trial‚Äù. It‚Äôs a prosecutors brief with no one to speak for the other side, etc. Even some supporters of the committee say that in a way it is if not a show trial then a brief, a prosecutors argument.‚Äî Josh Marshall (@joshtpm) July 23, 2022The Arkansas Senator emphasized that January 6 evidence presented by Democrats is mostly lacking context, while Pelosi has yet to release all video footage from the protest.
image_caption: WASHINGTON, DC ‚Äì OCTOBER 27: Sen. Tom Cotton (R-AR) questions U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland as he testifies at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing about oversight of the Department of Justice on October 27, 2021 in Washington, DC. (Photo by Tasos Katopodis-Pool/Getty Images)

story_headline: Rep. Jordan believes Trump will run in 2024
story_copy: Rep. Jordan believes Trump will run in 2024Rep. Jim Jordan on Capitol Hill in Washington. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 3:50 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022GOP representative Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) said he believes former President Trump will run in 2024. The Congressman made the comment during an interview on Sunday, in which he also said he is going to do everything he can to help Trump win.‚Äù If he wins, and that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm for,‚Äù Jordan said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been for that. Since he left on January 20, I wanted him to run in 2024. I think he‚Äôs going to. I think he is the right candidate.‚ÄùThe Republican said he doesn‚Äôt think January 6 will impact Trump‚Äôs chances and added that the American people know he will fight for them. Jordan also predicted America is going to be ‚Äúso much better off‚Äù if Trump is GOP presidential nominee in 2024 and wins.Trump has made remarks over recent months expressing openness to another run for the presidency in 2024. Jordan recalled the Trump administration‚Äôs use of a whiteboard to¬†catalogue¬†the fulfillment of Trump‚Äôs campaign promises.‚ÄúWe have never had a president who did more of what he said he would do than President Trump,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúI remember early on when I was in the White House they were in the West Wing in one of the offices. They had a whiteboard on the wall and literally they had every single policy and every single promise that President Trump made to the American people in the campaign of 2016. They were literally just checking them off as he did them.‚ÄùWondering where "Leave White House in 7 months" is on Bannon's whiteboard pic.twitter.com/O7UvFtA7y1‚Äî Chris Lu (@ChrisLu44) August 18, 2017In a @TPUSA straw poll today at their summit in Tampa, young conservatives overwhelmingly selected Trump as their choice for president if he launched a re-election bid.DeSantis was a distant second. pic.twitter.com/q4Pl9iPNro‚Äî Julia üá∫üá∏ (@Jules31415) July 24, 2022Jordan‚Äôs remarks come as recent polling indicates Trump would be the front runner for the GOP nomination if he were to launch a bid for the White House.
image_caption: Rep. Jim Jordan on Capitol Hill in Washington. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci, File)

story_headline: Wyo. super PAC releases ‚Äòfed up‚Äô anti-Cheney ad
story_copy: Wyo. super PAC releases ‚Äòfed up‚Äô anti-Cheney adOAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:16 PM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 26, 2022A Republican super PAC launched a new ad in Wyoming, slamming Rep. Liz Cheney (R-Wyo.) ahead of the state‚Äôs primary election. The 30-second spot titled ‚ÄúFed Up‚Äù was released Tuesday by the Wyoming Values PAC.The commercial claims Cheney left conservative values a long time ago and suggests it‚Äôs time for a change. It also features challenger Harriet Hageman who assured she will fight the Cheney-Pelosi agenda. The anti-Cheney ad cost about half-a-million dollars and will air throughout the state up until the August 16 primary.Ôªø

story_headline: US State Dept. condemns Myanmar executions
story_copy: US State Dept. condemns Myanmar executionsMyanmar nationals living in Thailand hold the pictures of deposed Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi as they protest outside Myanmar‚Äôs embassy in Bangkok, Thailand, Tuesday, July 26, 2022. International outrage over Myanmar‚Äôs execution of four political prisoners is intensifying with grassroots protests and strong condemnation from world governments. (AP Photo/Sakchai Lalit)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:27 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 26, 2022The Biden administration is looking to put pressure on Myanmar‚Äôs military junta. At a press briefing Monday, State Department spokesman Ned Price condemned Myanmar‚Äôs government, which has been run by it‚Äôs military since a coup in 2021, for executing four pro-democracy activists.Secretary of State Antony Blinken also issued a statement, calling the actions irreprehensible while claiming it adds to the killing of more than 2,100 residents and 700,000 people displaced from their home country. Both Blinken and Price warned this only shows how far Myanmar‚Äôs government is disregarding human rights.ÔªøEarlier in the day, the country announced its first set of executions in nearly 50 years. Among the dead include veteran activist Ko Jimmy and former lawmaker Phyo Zeya Thaw who were charged and convicted last month of violating counterterrorism laws.¬† The other two activists were reportedly convicted of killing a woman alleged to be an informant for the military. Some humanitarian organizations have claimed these trials were not conducted fairly.‚ÄúThe depravity of the Myanmar military junta knows no bounds,‚Äù stated Phil Robertson of Human Rights Watch. ‚ÄúThese are four political prisoners, they were brought up in front of a military tribunal that was a closed trial. Crimes against humanity is obviously not enough for the Myanmar military junta: now they are engaged in executing prisoners.‚ÄùMeanwhile, other activists on the ground are lamenting the military‚Äôs increasingly brazen attacks on its civilian population. Some believe troops‚Äô attempts to take out opposition forces are just to cement their power and eliminate any threat to it. Others say these attempts will be counterproductive and will only rally civilians behind the pro-democracy movement.‚ÄúThere will be more resistance,¬† this will escalate the revolution, including the urban guerrilla fighters,‚Äù said Thinzar Shunlei Yi, a Myanmar activist. ‚ÄúThere will be more defensive war in different areas. This action is just like a call to war, a call for war to their own people.‚ÄùIn the meantime, the US State Department is calling on Myanmar‚Äôs military to cease further plans to execute civilians and is urging the international community to sanction Myanmar. Cambodia‚Äôs prime minister, who chairs the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, has condemned Myanmar‚Äôs behavior and is looking to solve the political crisis in Myanmar at a regional level.
image_caption: Myanmar nationals living in Thailand hold the pictures of deposed Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi as they protest outside Myanmar‚Äôs embassy in Bangkok, Thailand, Tuesday, July 26, 2022. International outrage over Myanmar‚Äôs execution of four political prisoners is intensifying with grassroots protests and strong condemnation from world governments. (AP Photo/Sakchai Lalit)

story_headline: NYC Mayor Adams flip-flops on migrants flooding city
story_copy: NYC Mayor Adams flip-flops on migrants flooding cityFILE ‚Äì Mayor Eric Adams speaks during a graduation ceremony at Madison Square Garden, on July 1, 2022, in New York. (AP Photo/John Minchillo, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:51 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 26, 2022New York City Mayor Eric Adams sounded the alarm on the surge of illegal aliens coming to the Big Apple. During a press conference Sunday, Adams warned the city about the massive influx.One of his campaign priorities was standing up for ‚Äúundocumented New Yorkers‚Äù by making sure NYC remained a ‚Äúsanctuary city.‚Äù He doubled down on that promise by informing residents that right now ‚Äúthis is an all hands on deck‚Äù moment.ÔªøAdams went on to say residents must all be on board after asking the administration for help last week while calling the migrants a ‚Äúreal burden on New Yorkers.‚Äù Border towns are familiar with NYC‚Äôs plight as more than 3 million migrants have surged into the country since Joe Biden took office.Adams pleaded with the White House to provide aid to help accommodate the more than 2,800 people who recently entered the city‚Äôs shelter system. The Mayor was quick to blame migrants sent by Texas and Arizona, but also acknowledged federal migrant flights have contributed to the total sum. Adams listed a number of services for migrants he would like to be financed by federal tax dollars.Meanwhile, the Mayor of Arizona‚Äôs border town of Yuma, Douglas Nicholls, spoke with One America‚Äôs Alicia Summers to share his thoughts on the ongoing crisis.While Democrats continue to say Texas Governor Greg Abbott‚Äôs plan to bus illegal aliens from his state to Washington D.C. is purely political, proponents of the strategy have said it‚Äôs acting as intended. It grabs the attention of those who are seemingly blind to the events at the border.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Mayor Eric Adams speaks during a graduation ceremony at Madison Square Garden, on July 1, 2022, in New York. (AP Photo/John Minchillo, File)

story_headline: VP Harris travels to Ind. amid state abortion law hearing
story_copy: VP Harris travels to Ind. amid state abortion law hearingVice President Kamala Harris meets with Indiana Democratic legislators to discuss reproductive rights at the Indiana State Library in Indianapolis, Monday, July 25, 2022. The Indiana legislature is starting a special legislative session to address new abortion legislation and refunds to residents from the states budget surplus. (AP Photo/Michael Conroy)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:23 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 26, 2022The Biden administration deployed Kamala Harris to Indiana as the state becomes the first to hold a special session to discuss abortion laws. On Monday, Hoosier lawmakers discussed a bill that would ban abortions except in cases of rape or incest.KAMALA HARRIS: "Women are getting pregnant every day in America, and this is a real issue." pic.twitter.com/hWErnMztJf‚Äî RNC Research (@RNCResearch) July 24, 2022Indiana‚Äôs current abortion laws state the procedure is legal up to 22-weeks. Women also reportedly have to undergo an ultrasound and wait 18-hours before receiving the procedure. Supporters of the new restrictions stress they are not trying to ‚Äúcriminalize‚Äù women, but support them in ‚Äúbringing healthy babies into the world.‚Äù‚ÄúIf government does not protect life, our first right, none of the other rights in the Bill of Rights matter,‚Äù said Nathaniel Mervar, a pro-life activist. ‚ÄúAnd for 50 years, this chamber has told us that we cannot abolish abortion because of Roe v. Wade. Now, Roe v. Wade has been overturned and yet there is no bill to ban abortion outright.‚ÄùHowever, the Vice President accused proponents of the bill of not understanding biology. Harris broke with her party by exclusively using the word ‚Äúwoman‚Äù to describe someone who gets pregnant while claiming abortion is integral to women‚Äôs health.‚ÄúAnd if you know how a woman‚Äôs body works, then you will understand that at the point that the vast majority of women realize they are pregnant, abortion will essentially be banned,‚Äù she stated.While speaking at a press conference in Indianapolis, Harris claimed abortion is both constitutional and compatible with any religious belief.‚ÄúOne does not have to abandon your faith or your beliefs to agree that the government should not be making this decision for her,‚Äù she noted.Harris‚Äô respect for bodily autonomy did not apply to the unvaccinated as the Biden administration pushed for a private employer COVID-19 vaccine mandate last year.Indiana Rep. Jackie Walorski, a Republican, chastised Harris‚Äô visit by calling it ‚Äúout-of-touch‚Äù with the needs of Hoosiers. She argued that while inflation rages and gas prices soar, the Biden administration is focusing on its left-wing agenda.‚ÄúAs Indiana leads the nation in protecting women and defending life, Vice President Kamala Harris is radically out-of-touch with Hoosiers‚Äô values and priorities,‚Äù Walorski stated. ‚ÄúInflation is raging, gas prices are out of control, illicit fentanyl is killing our neighbors every day and yet, Kamala Harris will fly over the Heartland and ignore these Democrat-inflicted crises until it fits the Biden administration‚Äôs left-wing agenda. As we‚Äôll see in November, Hoosiers aren‚Äôt buying what Biden and Harris are selling.‚Äù¬†The chairman of Indiana‚Äôs Republican Party echoed these statements, saying there is no need of any Washington D.C. in Indiana.
image_caption: Vice President Kamala Harris meets with Indiana Democratic legislators to discuss reproductive rights at the Indiana State Library in Indianapolis, Monday, July 25, 2022. The Indiana legislature is starting a special legislative session to address new abortion legislation and refunds to residents from the states budget surplus. (AP Photo/Michael Conroy)

Wadevvaccine mandateVaccineswoman SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: 6 Democrat staffers arrested for protesting in Sen. Schumer‚Äôs office
story_copy: 6 Democrat staffers arrested for protesting in Sen. Schumer‚Äôs officeSenate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., speaks with reporters following a closed-door caucus lunch, at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, July 19, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:32 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 26, 2022Six congressional staffers were arrested after protesting in Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer‚Äôs (D-N.Y.) office. On Monday, the progressive staffers confronted the lawmaker to restart so-called green energy negotiations with =Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.)Last month, talks with Manchin on a climate, energy and the tax bill fell through. One of the demonstrators claimed they were pushing Schumer to combat so-called climate change while Democrats still hold both Houses of Congress.USCP arrested six House staffers this afternoon for protesting inside @SenSchumer‚Äôs office demanding the majority leader restart negotiations to pass climate legislation.‚ÄúHe‚Äôs giving up, but some of us are going to live through the climate crisis,‚Äù @saaaauuull told @NBCNews pic.twitter.com/YDHc0N1FFD‚Äî Julia Jester (@JulesJester) July 25, 2022Capitol Police released the protesters shortly after. The demonstrators are staffers for a number of House progressives, including Rep. Ilhan Omar, (D-Minn.), Rep. Cori Bush (D-Mo.) and Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.).This morning, 5 of my coworkers and I were arrested for peacefully protesting in @SenSchumer‚Äôs office. Amid record heat waves & worsening climate disasters, we called on the Majority Leader to pass climate policy as a matter of urgency. His office called the police. pic.twitter.com/yaw02mKILO‚Äî esp‚ú® (@emmasage__) July 25, 2022According to reports, talks between Manchin and Schumer were put on hold following the release of the Consumer Price Index report. The data showed an alarming 9.1 percent increase in inflation over the last year.
image_caption: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., speaks with reporters following a closed-door caucus lunch, at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, July 19, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)

story_headline: Dr. Fauci claims booster is best against new variant
story_copy: Dr. Fauci claims booster is best against new variantFILE ‚Äì Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, speaks during the daily briefing at the White House in Washington, Dec. 1, 2021. \Fauci, the government‚Äôs top infectious disease expert, says he plans to retire by the end of President Joe Biden‚Äôs term in January 2025. Fauci, 81, became director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in 1984 and has advised seven presidents. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:51 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 26, 2022White House Chief Medical Adviser, Dr. Anthony Fauci is recommending Americans get another booster shot for the latest variant of COVID-19. In an exclusive with The Hill on Monday, he said getting the jab is hi ‚Äúbest guess‚Äù at beating the new variant.His comments come as the BA.5 is the most widespread variant currently causing infections. In the meantime, Dr. Fauci claimed the FDA will likely approve booster shots for this new variant by the fall. This comes despite studies showing natural immunity is longer lasting than vaccine immunity.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs always the possibility that you‚Äôre going to have the evolution of another variant and hopefully if that occurs it will vary off from the BA.5 only slightly in the sense of being a sub-sub-lineage of it and not something entirely different,‚Äù said Dr. Fauci.The NIAID director has continued to defend COVID-19 vaccine mandates. He was asked why vaccines are still mandated in many places when he himself was quoted as saying that everyone would come into contact with COVID and most would contract it anyway. Dr. Fauci said vaccines, particularly boosters, prevent progression of the disease to hospitalization as the reason for the continued push.Dr. Fauci, who tested positive for the virus twice, also praised his Paxlovid regimen as he said it gave him a relatively mild disease. Meanwhile, the President‚Äôs physician said Joe Biden‚Äôs COVID symptoms are almost completely resolved. Dr. Kevin O‚ÄôConnor gave the update Monday in a letter to Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre.President Trump gets #COVID:‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the end of the world!‚Äù Fauci and Biden get COVID:‚ÄúNo big deal.‚Äù‚Äî Rep. Jim Jordan (@Jim_Jordan) July 25, 2022O‚ÄôConnor said the President is experiencing nasal congestion and hoarseness, but other than that his pulse, blood pressure, respiratory rate and temperature remain normal. Biden completed his fourth treatment of Paxolvid and will continue taking the medication as planned. He will also continue to isolate according CDC recommendations.According to reports from governments around the world, people who received the COVID vaccines are suffering far more injuries and deaths than those who didn‚Äôt. One America‚Äôs Pearson Sharp has more.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, speaks during the daily briefing at the White House in Washington, Dec. 1, 2021. \Fauci, the government‚Äôs top infectious disease expert, says he plans to retire by the end of President Joe Biden‚Äôs term in January 2025. Fauci, 81, became director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in 1984 and has advised seven presidents. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh, File)

story_headline: Brooklyn pastor robbed at gunpoint during sermon
story_copy: Brooklyn pastor robbed at gunpoint during sermonBishop Lamor Miller-Whitehead speaks with the media about his attempt to negotiate the surrender of a man accused of gunning down a stranger on a New York City subway train, on Tuesday, May 24, 2022, in New York. Miller-Whitehead, a preacher known for his close friendship with New York City‚Äôs mayor, was robbed of more than $1 million worth of jewelry Sunday, July 24, 2022, by armed bandits who crashed his Brooklyn church service. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:58 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, July 26, 2022A Brooklyn, New York pastor, known as the ‚ÄúBling Bling Bishop,‚Äù was robbed at gunpoint of the more than $1 million in jewelry he was wearing while delivering Sunday‚Äôs sermon. It was all captured on the church‚Äôs livestream from that morning.Police said three masked men kicked in the front doors of Bishop Lamor Whitehead‚Äôs Leaders of Tomorrow Church. They held guns on the deacons at the doors while the 100 congregants dropped to the floor.US Pastor, Congregation Robbed During Church ServiceAn American pastor, Bishop Lamor Miller-Whitehead and members of his congregation were robbed of about $400K in jewellery during a live-streamed church service on Sunday. pic.twitter.com/tesr4cd8O8‚Äî Punch Newspapers (@MobilePunch) July 25, 2022Whitehead believes he was targeted because of the publicity he received when he turned in a suspect in the fatal subway shooting of 48-year-old Daniel Enriquez back in May.‚ÄúI turned him in, but the media called me the bling, bling bishop,‚Äù said Whitehead. ‚ÄúThey had my Rolls Royce car all over everywhere and I feel that that played a part in this.Fortunately, no one was injured in the incident, but the pastor said his church is traumatized.‚ÄúThe women and children are still crying,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúThese men, they need to turn themselves in. I forgive you and I‚Äôm praying for you, and I hope that God deliver you from the mindset of who you are at this time.‚ÄùMayor Eric Adams and top NYPD officals have vowed to find the suspects.
image_caption: Bishop Lamor Miller-Whitehead speaks with the media about his attempt to negotiate the surrender of a man accused of gunning down a stranger on a New York City subway train, on Tuesday, May 24, 2022, in New York. Miller-Whitehead, a preacher known for his close friendship with New York City‚Äôs mayor, was robbed of more than $1 million worth of jewelry Sunday, July 24, 2022, by armed bandits who crashed his Brooklyn church service. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer)

story_headline: Investigation underway after shots fired at Dallas airport
story_copy: Investigation underway after shots fired at Dallas airportA traveler makes her way past emergency responders standing outside the ticketing and check in area at Dallas Love Field in Dallas, Monday, July 25, 2022. A 37-year-old woman fired several gunshots, apparently at the ceiling, inside of Dallas‚Äô Love Field Airport on Monday before an officer shot and wounded her, authorities said. (AP Photo/Tony Gutierrez)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 5:10 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Authorities are investigating a shooting which prompted evacuations at Dallas Love Field Airport. The FAA ordered a ground stop at the airport shortly after 11 a.m. local time due to the active shooter situation. Dallas Chief of Police Eddie Garcia said 37-year-old Portia Odufuwa began firing a handgun and a police officer engaged the suspect. He claimed that the woman entered the airport and went into a restroom to change clothes. Garcia expressed that the woman exited the restroom wearing a hoody and opened fire. Most of the shots appeared to be directed toward the ceiling.‚ÄúAt this point, we don‚Äôt know where exactly the individual was aiming,‚Äù Garcia stated. ‚ÄúFrom what we are seeing she was aiming at the ceiling. There are several rounds that were found.‚ÄùAn officer working inside confronted Odufuwa and shot her in her lower extremities. The suspect was taken to Parkland Memorial Hospital in an unknown condition. No further information about her or the motivation behind the shooting or who dropped her off at the airport has been confirmed by police. There were no other injuries.The investigation is ongoing and Garcia said he expected elements to change as more is learned about what happened. Dallas Police said they do not plan to release any other statements until Tuesday afternoon. The Dallas FBI and ATF are assisting Dallas Police in the investigation.The shooting wasn‚Äôt the first violent incident at the airport. In 2016, a police officer shot and wounded a man outside of Love Field after police said he advanced toward the officer with large landscaping rocks in his hands after battering his ex-girlfriend‚Äôs car with a traffic cone and rocks as she dropped him off at the airport.‚ÄúI‚Äôm thankful to the Dallas Police Department, the Transportation Security Administration and the dedicated Love Field staff for their swift response in keeping people safe,‚Äù City Council member Jesse Moreno voiced. ‚ÄúThis is something they do every day for people who travel to and from Dallas.‚ÄùEarlier I spoke with an eye witness who described what he and his wife saw inside at the ticketing counter.  They said a woman said she was going to, ‚ÄúMake an announcement‚Äù then they saw her pull out a gun. @NBCDFW pic.twitter.com/KSzsma0iJY‚Äî Sophia Beausoleil (@SophiaNBC5) July 25, 2022Inside Dallas Love Field, swarms of passengers wait for TSA to open back up following the airport shooting. pic.twitter.com/NAiJTe1Oge‚Äî Markie Martin (@MarkieMartin) July 25, 2022Flights bound for the airport were temporarily delayed during the incident.
image_caption: A traveler makes her way past emergency responders standing outside the ticketing and check in area at Dallas Love Field in Dallas, Monday, July 25, 2022. A 37-year-old woman fired several gunshots, apparently at the ceiling, inside of Dallas‚Äô Love Field Airport on Monday before an officer shot and wounded her, authorities said. (AP Photo/Tony Gutierrez)
